IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
FOR THE DISTRICT OF DELAWARE

UNITED STATES OF AMERICA,

Plaintiff,
v. : Crim. No. 18-29-LPS-1
CHRISTOPHER HURD,
Defendant.

ORDER

At Wilmington this 29th day of December, 2021, having reviewed Defendant
Christopher Hurd’s Motion for Reduction in Sentence Pursuant to 18 U.S.C. § 3582(c)(1)(A)@)
(D.L. 88), the government’s response (D.I. 90), and Hurd’s reply (D.I. 91), IT IS HEREBY
ORDERED that Hurd’s Motion (D.L. 88) is DENIED.

As an initial matter, the parties dispute whether Hurd’s motion is properly before the
Court, considering the Court’s January 8, 2021 denial of Hurd’s first motion to reduce his
sentence to time served (D.I. 81). (Compare D.I. 90 (“This Court made no mention in its Order
that Defendant could renew his motion at a later date.”) with D.L. 91 (arguing that because first
motion was “not denied with prejudice,” Hurd can “bring the matter up at a later date” and
instant motion is “a whole new motion,” as it requests only 30-month reduction and presents new
extraordinary and compelling circumstances)) The Court need not resolve this dispute and will
proceed to the merits of the new motion.

The instant motion asserts substantially the same arguments as Hurd’s first motion, and
consequently suffers from the same deficiency. Hurd has failed to show his early release would

not pose a danger to the community. In reaching the same conclusion with respect to Hurd’s first

motion, the Court considered the nature of Hurd’s underlying offense, including that Hurd
“deliberately laced already-dangerous drugs . . . with even more dangerous substances,” his
extensive criminal history, and his record of “hostility towards probation officers and repeated
violations of court-ordered supervision.” (D.I. 87 at 3) These factors remain unchanged,
relevant, and persuasive today. While the Court appreciates the impact Hurd’s drug addiction
may have had on his decision-making and commends Hurd for being “drug free for 47 months
now” (D.L. 88 at 8), it is nevertheless not persuaded that Hurd would not pose a danger to society

upon release.

uf

HONORABLE LEONARD P. STARK
UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE
